<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," alt="" width="348" height="196" /></p>
<p><strong>Litecoin</strong> (<strong>LTC</strong> or <strong>≈Å</strong>) is a <a title="" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peer-to-peer">peer-to-peer</a> <a title="Peer-to-peer" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency">cryptocurrency</a> and <a title="Open-source software" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open-source_software">open-source software</a> project released under the <a title="" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MIT_License">MIT/X11 license</a>. Litecoin was an early bitcoin spinoff or <a title="Cryptocurrency" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cryptocurrency#Altcoins">altcoin</a>, starting in October 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-WIRED_2-0" class="reference"></sup> In technical details, Litecoin is nearly identical to <a title="Bitcoin" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin">Bitcoin</a>.</p>
<p><strong>Differences from Bitcoin</strong></p>
<p>Litecoin is different in some ways from <a title="Bitcoin" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitcoin">Bitcoin</a>.</p>
<ul>
<li>The Litecoin Network aims to process a block every 2.5 minutes, rather than Bitcoin's 10 minutes. This allows Litecoin to confirm transactions much faster than Bitcoin.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"></sup></li>
<li>Litecoin uses <a title="Scrypt" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scrypt">scrypt</a> in its <a class="mw-redirect" title="Proof-of-work" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof-of-work">proof-of-work</a> algorithm, a sequential memory-hard function requiring <a title="Asymptotic analysis" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asymptotic_analysis">asymptotically</a> more memory than an algorithm which is not memory-hard.</li>
</ul>
<p>Due to Litecoin's use of the script algorithm, <a title="Field-programmable gate array" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field-programmable_gate_array">FPGA</a> and <a title="Application-specific integrated circuit" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Application-specific_integrated_circuit">ASIC</a> devices made for mining Litecoin are more complicated to create and more expensive to produce than they are for Bitcoin, which uses SHA-256.<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"></sup></p>
<p>When it comes to Litecoin as a method of payment, in early days there was correlation to Bitcoin in terms of extended payment patterns. Although one might assume that payment patterns of Litecoin would converge to Bitcoin, it has been found that there is little correlation of the payment patterns of Litecoin vs Bitcoin today, and these patterns continue to diverge over time.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"></sup></p>
